articles.headline: Start-Up Fervor Shifts to Energy in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Former dot-com entrepreneurs have found a new purpose in transforming the $1 trillion domestic energy market.
articles.abstract: Former dot-com entrepreneurs have found a new purpose in transforming the $1 trillion domestic energy market.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 — Silicon Valley’s dot-com era may be giving way to the watt-com era.

articles.headline: Answering Latin Left, Bush Pledges to Help Poor
articles.snippet: The president’s Latin American tour represented an attempt to stave off growing anti-American sentiment.
articles.abstract: The president’s Latin American tour represented an attempt to stave off growing anti-American sentiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: MÉRIDA, Mexico, March 13 — In the slums of Brazil, in the impoverished villages of Guatemala and finally here in Mexico, President Bush promised this week to deliver “social justice” to poor and struggling Latin Americans left behind by the global economy.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: Pakistani Militants Hit Targets Close to Home
articles.snippet: Suicide bombers have recently turned on Pakistan itself as Islamic militants threaten to open a new front.
articles.abstract: Suicide bombers have recently turned on Pakistan itself as Islamic militants threaten to open a new front.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Along the Afghan border, not far from this northwestern city, Islamic militants have used a firm foothold over the past year to train and dispatch suicide bombers against American and NATO forces in Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Decaf Being Joined by De-Heartburn
articles.snippet: Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee war: a “stomach friendly” coffee for Americans who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff.
articles.abstract: Folgers has opened a new flank in the coffee war: a “stomach friendly” coffee for Americans who think they can no longer handle the hard stuff.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much of the action in the coffee war of the last few years has been over the best-tasting brand. There, McDonald’s and Dunkin’ Donuts are battling Starbucks, not to mention Caribou Coffee, Peet’s Coffee & Tea and numerous others. And Burger King offers a “turbo-strength” version.

articles.headline: Bad Loans Put Wall St. in a Swoon
articles.snippet: Stocks fell broadly and sharply after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further.
articles.abstract: Stocks fell broadly and sharply after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell broadly and sharply yesterday afternoon after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further before showing signs of improvement.

articles.headline: WhoseTube? Viacom Sues Google Over Video Clips
articles.snippet: Accusing Google and its YouTube site of “massive copyright infringement,” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages.
articles.abstract: Accusing Google and its YouTube site of “massive copyright infringement,” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 — Since it bought YouTube last October, Google has been chasing deals that would give it the right to put mainstream video programming on the site. Just a few weeks ago, Google’s chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, seemed confident that this courtship of old-line media companies would prove fruitful.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Mutual Funds at Some Risk on Mortgages
articles.snippet: The turmoil tearing through the residential mortgage market will probably harm everyday investors.
articles.abstract: The turmoil tearing through the residential mortgage market will probably harm everyday investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mutual funds held mortgage-related debt securities issued by the subprime lenders New Century Financial, NovaStar Financial and others at the end of last year, indicating that everyday investors are among those who will probably be hurt by the turmoil that is tearing through the residential mortgage market.

articles.headline: H.P. Restarts as Spy Case Lingers On
articles.snippet: The revelations that a dysfunctional board spied on its members and on journalists still casts a shadow on a company that by most measures is performing well.
articles.abstract: The revelations that a dysfunctional board spied on its members and on journalists still casts a shadow on a company that by most measures is performing well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark V. Hurd, the chairman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, would prefer that the discussion at the annual meeting this afternoon focus on the company’s future, not its past.
